In this post we provide six common website design errors that people fall into that might actually hurt, rather than help, their website serve their purpose.

Tech News

Washington Sues Facebook and Google Over Failure to Disclose Political Ad Spending

The state of Washington filed lawsuits in state court alleging that Facebook and Google failed to abide by campaign finance laws with respect to political ads placed on their online platforms as far back as 2013. Washington state campaign finance laws require commercial advertisers that sell political advertising to maintain information about those who purchase advertising. The lawsuits allege that the companies failed to maintain this information and seek damages and injunctive relief.

Europe’s Top Court Takes a Broad View of Privacy Responsibilities Around Platforms

The Court of Justice of the European Union held that an administrator of a fan page on Facebook is jointly responsible with Facebook for the processing of the data of visitors to the page, although the court emphasized that “joint responsibility” does not necessarily imply equal responsibility. With the recent implementation of the General Data Protection Regulation 2016/679 (GDPR), EU member states are showing a willingness to hold companies that collect large amounts of user data to increasingly high standards.

AT&T’s Time Warner Takeover Wins Judge’s Approval in Defeat for Justice Dept.

A federal judge in DC approved the merger between AT&T and Time Warner, finding that the Justice Department had not proved that the merger would lead to fewer choices for consumers and higher prices for TV and internet services. According to the authors of this article, this decision could lead to “a wave of corporate takeovers.”

First State Net Neutrality Law Takes Effect, Countering FCC Repeal

A handful of states rushed to pass their own net neutrality rules after the FCC repealed the federal net neutrality rules in December 2017. The federal regulations were officially defunct on June 11, and on that same day, the State of Washington became the first US state to enact a net neutrality law to replace those repealed by the FCC. The state law prohibits internet service providers from blocking or throttling lawful internet traffic and from charging online services for prioritization.

New Jersey Just Legalized Online Sports Betting

After the US Supreme Court struck down part of a federal law prohibiting states from authorizing sports gambling, New Jersey (the state involved in that case) governor Phil Murphy signed a bill legalizing sports gambling in that state. According to the author of this article, the bill is expected to open the door for many online gambling websites, particularly ahead of major events.

Most Facebook Users Hit By Cambridge Analytica Scandal Are Californians

CNET reports that most of the users affected by the Cambridge Analytica data breach reside in California. When accounting for differences in overall population, however, Facebook’s recently released state-by-state breakdown of the data improperly shared with Cambridge Analytica show that Washington, DC, has the highest percentage of users affected by the incident.

Judge Says ‘Literal But Nonsensical’ Google Translation Isn’t Consent For Police Search

A recent decision by a federal district court judge illustrates how the limitations of translation technology may sometimes serve to secure individuals’ constitutional rights. The case involved police officers requesting to search the vehicle of an individual who did not speak English. The officers apparently tried to use Google Translate to ask for the driver’s consent to search the car, but reportedly asked instead whether they may search for the car. The judge ruled that the driver’s consent to this nonsensical question did not meet the Fourth Amendment standard of “intelligent, knowing, and voluntary” consent.

SEO News

SEO For Google Now Harder? What Has Changed Over The Past Few Years?

Why do SEO techniques employed just a couple of years ago no longer seem as effective in 2018? If you are doing the same things, rather than evolving, this could be the culprit. Competition has been steadily increasing among web pages for the same keywords. Additionally, Google expects better quality content than it did a few years ago, as well as strategically-chosen, relevant links. This necessitates the implementation of an ever-evolving SEO strategy to ensure your site continues to rank strongly.

Google Clears Up Confusion Around Mobile-First Indexing

Recent misunderstandings about Google’s mobile-first indexing prompted the company to publish a series of tweets to address users’ confusion. Google’s tweets touched on crawled counts and cached pages, as well as explained how URLs are indexed within its search engine. They also referenced Google’s anticipated July mobile speed update, among other topics.

Google Testing AMP Label in Search Ads

Advertisers who use Google AdWords with AMP landing pages may see a special badge next to their ads, a feature that Google is testing to improve their advertisers’ experiences. The AMP badge is gray and circular, with a white lightning icon at its center, and appears next to a text ad’s description. AMP landing pages have been available to any advertiser who uses AdWords since last September.

Google to Better Communicate Why Certain Ads Shown

Back in 2011, Google introduced a feature called “Why this ad?” It explained to users why they were being shown specific ads, but up until now the feature had shown up only in a limited number of places. Now, it will appear more broadly in a variety of places: Google’s search results, its Maps app, Gmail, YouTube, Google Play, and virtually every website and app that partners with the company to show ads. The intent is to provide users with more control and transparency with respect to their ad experiences.

Social Media News

Facebook Let Select Companies Have “Special Access” to User Data, Per Report

Long after most developers’ access was cut off to user data, Facebook maintained secret deals with select companies, allowing them “special access to user records.” Facebook’s vice president of product partners framed them as “short-term extensions” for some companies. Although Facebook has not provided a full list of companies it provided extensions of this nature to, Ars Technica maintains that such deals were extended to several companies, including the Royal Bank of Canada and Nissan Motor Company.

New Twitter Updates Aim to Make Content Easier to Find

New Twitter features are on the way. An enhanced timeline, notifications, and the ‘Explore’ and ‘Moments’ sections are all getting updates, with the intent to make content simpler for users to find. Twitter’s goal is to change how its users locate information like breaking news, live events, and other specific topics that are important to them.

Facebook Privacy Goof Makes Posts By 14 Million Users Readable to Anyone

In June, Facebook acknowledged that it had accidentally made public the posts of 14 million users who had designated that their posts be shared to a more limited number of users. Facebook disclosed that its technicians stopped private posts from going public on May 22, but it took an additional five days to restore the privacy settings to the posts that had been affected. Facebook eventually notified the users whose posts were among the affected. It also referred these users to its privacy basics page.

Facebook’s Ad Rules Are Forcing News Outlets to Register as Political Advertisers

During the last week of May, Facebook began enforcing new rules surrounding political advertising. The rules impose strict verification requirements for any accounts that promote political content, which has led to a wave of ad suspensions—even for neutral content in some instances. The process itself seems to have caught many publications off-guard, as it requires strict verification via codes sent to US mailing addresses. In the first week of enforcement alone, The Verge reported that 85 new posts had fallen afoul of the enforcement rules.

Instagram Decides Not to Alert Users When Screenshots Are Taken

After testing a feature that would alert users when others took screenshots of their stories, Instagram has confirmed that it will not be releasing the feature after all. The company is no longer testing the feature, and users can continue to take screenshots without being identified.

Facebook Will Ban Businesses From Running Ads if They Get Poor Customer Feedback

Under a new policy, businesses receiving negative customer feedback can potentially be prohibited from placing ads on Facebook. After making a purchase through a Facebook ad, users can send feedback directly to the social media giant, which will contact businesses receiving a large amount of poor feedback. Those companies will have an opportunity to improve before their ad space is reduced, though in cases where there is insufficient improvement, Facebook can ban a business’ ads completely.

Legal Industry News

Smart Contracts Taking Over: Pros, Cons, and How to Stay On Top of It All

As part of an ongoing series covering blockchain’s impacts on the legal industry, this article provides a primer on the benefits and drawbacks of using blockchain-powered smart contracts, which are transforming legal agreements and industries throughout the economy.

Judge Reprimanded for Posting Comment About Murder Case on Facebook

The Kentucky Judicial Conduct Commission professionally disciplined a state judge who had posted content on Facebook regarding a murder case that was pending in the district court where she serves as a judge. After sharing an article about the case and commenting that the defendant had been released hours after confessing to police, the judge was reprimanded on the grounds that her post ran afoul of judicial ethics rules requiring her to uphold the integrity of the judiciary, to behave in a manner that promotes public confidence in the judiciary, and refrain from making public statements that could impact pending cases.

ABA Asks House Members to Oppose Law Ending Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program

ABA President Hilarie Bass has written a letter to members of the US House of Representatives requesting that they oppose a provision of pending legislation that would eliminate the Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) program. The PROSPER Act is a higher education reform initiative that would, among other things, abolish PSLF, which provides loan forgiveness after 10 years of on-time payments for certain federal loans for lawyers and others who work for government or non-profit employers. The program was created in 2007 to encourage graduates with legal and other degrees to pursue careers in public service or public interest.

ABA President Says Separating Families Violates Civil Rights, Won’t Work and is Inhumane

ABA President Hilarie Bass sent a letter to US Attorney General Jeff Sessions and Department of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen criticizing the policy of separating immigrant children from parents who were arrested under the Trump administration’s “zero-tolerance” policy for entering the country illegally. Bass argued that family separation likely violates existing law protecting family integrity and due process. She also criticized the policy for being inhumane and traumatic, as well as ineffective as a deterrent given the extreme violence that most migrants from El Salvador, Guatemala, and Honduras are fleeing.

Judge Criticized for Stanford Swimmer’s Sexual Assault Sentence is Ousted in Recall Vote

Aaron Persky, the California state judge who was widely criticized for sentencing a Stanford swimmer to only a six month jail term in 2016 for sexual assault, has been recalled by voters in Santa Clara County. The recall effort was led by Stanford law professor Michele Dauber, and the number of California law professors supporting the recall eventually totaled 90. The state Commission on Judicial Performance received thousands of complaints about the sentence, but declined to impose discipline, citing a lack of clear and convincing evidence of bias or other misconduct. Persky has reportedly stated that he does not regret the sentencing and would handle the case the same way if faced with the decision again. He is the first California judge to be recalled since 1932.

ABA Techshow 2018 Examines Legal Profession’s Direction with Technology Emphasis

ABA Techshow 2018 recently took place in Chicago, and provided attendees with presentations and content on a wide variety of topics relevant to the legal profession, expanding beyond legal tech to include leadership, team building, and mindfulness. Other key subjects included the growing and potential role of blockchain, digital devices, and how to harness technology to create the next wave of legal innovation.
